CytOpT.Cytopt module

CytOpT.Cytopt.CytOpt(X_s, X_t, Lab_source, Lab_target=None, cell_type=None, names_pop=None, method=None, theta_true=None, eps=0.0001, n_iter=4000, power=0.99, step_grad=50, step=5, lbd=0.0001, n_out=1000, n_stoc=10, n_0=10, n_stop=1000, monitoring=True, minMaxScaler=True, thresholding=True)[source]

  • Comparison of methods

– Steps — Classification using optimal transport with reweighted proportions. — The target measure 𝛽 is reweighted in order to match the weight vector ℎ̂ estimated with 𝙲𝚢𝚝𝙾𝚙𝚝. — Approximation of the optimal dual vector u. In order to compute an approximation of the optimal transportation plan, we need to approximate 𝑃𝜀 . — Class proportions estimation with 𝙲𝚢𝚝𝙾𝚙𝚝 Descent-Ascent procedure Setting of the parameters — Minmax swapping procedure. Setting of the parameters — Plot all Bland-Altman

Parameters

  • X_t –

  • power –

  • step_grad –

  • lbd –

  • n_out –

  • n_stoc –

  • n_0 –

  • monitoring –

  • thresholding –

CytOpT.CytOpt_Descent_Ascent module

CytOpT.CytOpt_Descent_Ascent.Robbins_Wass(X_s, X_t, alpha, beta, eps=0, const=0.1, n_iter=10000)[source]

Function that calculates the approximation of the Wasserstein distance between mu and nu thanks to the Robbins-Monro Algorithm. X and Y are the supports of the source and target distribution. Alpha and beta are the weights of the distributions.

Parameters

  • X_s –

  • X_t –

  • alpha –

  • beta –

  • eps –

  • const –

  • n_iter –

Returns

CytOpT.CytOpt_Descent_Ascent.cost(X_s, y)[source]

Squared euclidean distance between y and the I points of X_s.

Parameters

  • X_s –

  • y –

Returns

CytOpT.CytOpt_Descent_Ascent.cytopt_desasc(X_s, X_t, Lab_source, eps=0.0001, n_out=4000, n_stoc=10, step_grad=50, const=0.1, theta_true=0)[source]

Function that estimates the class proportions in the target data set. It solves the minimization problem with a gradient descent method. At each iteration, a (sub)gradient of W^{eps}(alpha, beta) is approximated with stochastic optimization Techniques.

Parameters

  • X_s –

  • X_t –

  • Lab_source –

  • eps –

  • n_out –

  • n_stoc –

  • step_grad –

  • const –

  • theta_true –

Returns

CytOpT.CytOpt_Descent_Ascent.grad_h(f, X_s, y, alpha, eps=0)[source]

This function calculates the gradient of the function that we aim to maximize. The expectation of this function computed at a maximizer equals the wasserstein disctance, or its regularized counterpart.

Parameters

  • f –

  • X_s –

  • y –

  • alpha –

  • eps –

CytOpT.CytOpt_MinMax_Swapping module

CytOpT.CytOpt_MinMax_Swapping.cytopt_minmax(X_s, X_t, Lab_source, eps=0.0001, lbd=0.0001, n_iter=4000, step=5, power=0.99, theta_true=0, monitoring=False)[source]

Robbins-Monro algorithm to compute an approximate of the vector u^* solution of the maximization problem At each step, it is possible to evaluate the vector h_hat to study the convergence of this algorithm.

CytOpT.Label_Prop_sto module

CytOpT.Label_Prop_sto.Label_Prop_sto(L_source, f, X, Y, alpha, beta, eps)[source]

Function that calculates a classification on the target data thanks to the approximation of the transport plan and the classification of the source data. We got the approximation of the transport plan with the stochastic algorithm.

Parameters

  • L_source –

  • f –

  • X –

  • Y –

  • alpha –

  • beta –

  • eps –

CytOpT.Label_Prop_sto.c_transform(f, X_s, X_t=None, j=None, beta=None, eps=0)[source]

Calculate the c_transform of f in the non regularized case if eps=0. Otherwise, it computes the smooth c_transform with respect to the usual entropy.

CytOpT.Label_Prop_sto.h_function(f, X_s, X_t=None, j=None, beta=None, eps=0, alpha=0)[source]

Calculate the function h whose expectation equals the semi-dual loss. Maximizing the semi-dual loss allows us to compute the wasserstein distance.

  • X_s –

  • X_t –
